ARC from Young Adult Books CentralAnton's life in the Ukraine has been difficult. His mother died when he was young, and his father went off to fight in WWII and has not been heard from for a very long time. He has a supportive uncle, however, as well as his grandmother, Bubbe. When his village is overrun by the Nazis, a small group of people manage to escape, but they are found by Major Von Duesen, who is taking his directive to make the area free of Jews very seriously. Bubbe is angry and lets Von Duesen know, which gives Anton time to escape, although Bubbe is taken into custody so she can be questioned later, and two neighbors are shot to death. Anton is bound and determined to get Bubbe back, since she is all he has left. He manages to sabotage the truck she is on and free her, and they make their way to a cave where they set up a community and try to survive by stealing food from local farms. Von Duesen is angry that his career was ruined by Bubbe's group, and vows to find them and bring them to justice, especially since the war is not going well for the Nazis. How will Anton and his friends and family be able to survive until the Americans come and the Nazis retreat? There are never enough books about the Jewish experience in the Holocaust, and this is an interesting change from books where people are sent to camps. The details of escaping, living in the cave, and foraging for food are all vivid and helpful in understanding another facet of the Jewish experience. That this book is set in the Ukraine was also interesting, especially since Bubbe knew some German since the Ukraine had been so unsettled for so many years. Anton is motivated by survival, and also by helping to keep his family alive, and his efforts to do this are well described. It is Von Duesen, however, who is an interesting character study. While there had to have been many Germans who treated the Jews in horrific ways, there were probably a larger number who did what they were told to do lest they suffer themselves. Von Duesen is between these two types of people-- he's irritated by the Jews enough to commit atrocities, but the core of his motivation seems to be his own success. Therefore, when the Jews escape, he is more concerned that it will look bad for him with his superior officers than with the fact that there are Jews who escaped. I hadn't really thought about people who lingered in that area of self-absorbed cruelty. Kathryn Lasky's portrayal of Leni Riefenstahl in The Extra would be the closest book I can think of that has such a character. Fans of Dan Smith's WWII books, Will Osborne's Hitler's Secret, or even Hoose's nonfiction book, The Boys Who Challenged Hitler: Knud Pedersen and the Churchill Club will find the portrayal of Anton's struggle against the Nazis to be an excellent addition to the body of books about the Holocaust.

Did you know that speluncaphobia is the fear of being underground? I know if that was my fear, I wouldn't want to be a character in the Realistic Fiction novel ¨The Enemy Above¨ By Michael P. Spradlin, a book told from the perspectives of a young Jewish child, named Anton, and the gestapo officer trying to hunt Anton's family (and many other families) hiding spot down. I enjoyed this book because it had this sense of mature thinking, and it lead me to learn more about the Eastern Front of WW2.	Firstly, I enjoyed this book for the sense of growing more mature and more able in Anton's perspective. Throughout the novel, Anton has multiple points where he can outwit even the cunning Gestapo Officer to evade capture. The book throughout shows Anton's grandmother seeing him as more of a man than before the Germans arrived. However, throughout the book, there is also a more sinister perspective, through the Gestapo Officer, who is extremely intelligent, yet he is evaded time and time again. For his failures, he is demoted throughout the book, and I believe that this may have made all the Germans seem like idiots who are only focused on one thing, to the point they can't think about doing anything else.	Secondly, This novel lead me to learn more about the Eastern Front of WW2. This is because of a single note, given to the Gestapo officer by his brother, who had fought in Stalingrad. In the letter, he states, ¨... We are near defeat. The Russians will not give up... Not even the mighty Luftwaffe has been able to break the Russian spirit... Russian Infantry officers are shooting anyone who attempts to retreat on the spot. How can such a people be defeated? ... Our tanks are out of fuel, our planes will not fly in the cold.¨ (pg:125) For me, the line that talks about the Russian infantry officers sticks out the most. I mean, that is insane! When I read this, I thought it to be impossible. Then I thought about something I'd heard. Under Joseph Stalin's leadership, almost 11,000,000 Soldiers had died in the Eastern Front of WW2. At this, I realized it was most likely true, and then I wanted to dig more into this terrible side of the war. I wanted to see just how much each soldier went up against daily, see how past events might've made a difference, and line up the advantages and disadvantages each side faced in the bigger picture. I wanted to understand what each side had, and what they would need to survive a long, drawn-out battle.	In conclusion, I would recommend this book to anyone who wants to know a little more about daily life for the Jewish people who decided to hide away, or to those who enjoy suspenseful books, because it has much of both. I enjoyed for the feeling of growing older both in the mind and in the soul, and it lead me to learn more about the Eastern Front of WW2.

The Nazis were closing in on Anton and his family, and they had nowhere to go. This happened to Anton many times. The book I read for my genre exploration is The Enemy Above by Michael Spardlin. Anton was a young Jew teen who was living in the time of the Holocaust, his mother had died when he was young. His father had gone off to fight for the Ukrainian army, he was now living with his grandma which he called Bubbe. The Nazis were coming their way and now they had to flee their home to the underground village where other Jews were hiding. They did not know if they would be discovered or if someone had given away their location, Anton had to learn not to trust anyone.The Enemy Above is a great example of a historical fiction novel. This is because I know that a historical fiction novel always is set in the past or is revolved around a topic that happened in the past. In The Enemy Above the topic in the past is the Holocaust. Another example in Chains by Lauris Halse Anderson it states “to be made slaves for life in a Christian land.” We know that slavery is not legal today so this must be in the past. For one example in Chains it says that “Most of Madams friends have a slave to split wood.” Again , this talks about slavery so this would be in the past. So that is how I know that The Enemy Above is a historical fiction novel. Another example in Let America be America Again by Langston Hughes is “slavery’s scars.” This again talks about slavery which we all know is illegal so it has to be in the past. I enjoyed the book because I like learning about historical topics. I think teenagers would like this book it would not be for little kids because of the content and the topic of the book. So if you are looking to read a story about the Holocaust, I think that The Enemy Above is a good choice for you.

Let's get my complaint about this book out of the way first. I have read other books by Spradlin, but this one drove me absolutely bonkers for one simple reason. The author started way too many sentences with "and." It's not like he does it once or twice a page, but almost every other paragraph contains at least two sentences written this way. What makes it even worse is that these little "sentences" are not great pieces of writing. As an elementary school teacher, I am constantly trying to get my students not to start a sentence with the word "and." There is no way I am going to place this book on my classroom bookshelves, because it's doing exactly what I am teaching my students not to do.Now on to the story itself. It's nice to see authors tackling the subject of the Holocaust and doing so without prettying it up. Spradlin doesn't shy away from the violence and death associated with this horrible period in history. In fact, I think it might be a little too much for younger readers who are sensitive or not ready for this subject matter. I probably would recommend this book for 6th graders and higher, maybe mature 5th graders.The story follows a Jewish boy, Anton, and his grandmother as they try to hide from the invading Nazis and a Major bent on revenge. The majority of this book takes place over what is maybe a week. Each chapter switches between the boy and the major, each time filling in more details and providing more insights into each character. Overall, the book isn't bad. It's interesting, sad, and tense. I just wish it had been written better.

"Silence was life. Stillness was freedom."It is 1942 and Anton and his family live in the Ukraine. It is a dangerous time for Jews. As the German army is retreating from the Russians and the disastrous Battle of Stalingrad, Jews are being hunted by the Gestapo to achieve Judenfrei. And leading the charge is Major Van Duesen, a young, ambitious and ruthless officer.With artillery fire in the distance, Anton and his Bubbe head for a rendezvous with Anton's Uncle Dmitri, who will help them to a safe hiding place. That safe place is a cave, where there are several Jewish families in hiding. Anton immediately makes friends with Daniel and it is their task to map out the tunnels and find a potential emergency exit. But Major Van Duesen is indefatigable and he finds their hideout. As the others take the emergency exit, Bubbe stays to face down the Nazi, while Anton hides. "You Germans. Such zealots. So self-righteous. You are nothing more than puppets of a madman. And you cannot see the truth, even when it is right before your eyes." The more time she delays the Major, the better chance all the others will escape to the Priest's Grotto.But when the Major takes Bubbe off to be interrogated, Anton follows, knowing that he must help his grandmother escape at any cost.

Not the most exciting book I've ever read but there was nothing truly horrible about it and it was quick so I rounded up to three stars. Anton and his Bubbe need to find the other Jews and hide from the Gestapo as they take over Ukraine. As you can imagine there's lots of bad things happening and they have to stay hidden to stay alive. It's hard because Bubbe can't move very fast and Anton refuses to leave her behind. Honestly, this was the most thought-provoking part of the story. I kept wondering what I would do if I was old and holding people back. I don't think I could handle others dying because of me. I also wondered what I would do in Anton's position and had my grandmother telling me not to risk myself for her.Part of the book is also told from a gestapo agent trying to round up Jews. That provided a unique perspective. I wasn't bored while reading but it wasn't very captivating either. This is one of those tricky books where the reading level feels like 8-9 years old but the subject matter is for more mature kiddos.

When the German Gestap are about to capture twelve year old anton's Jewish Russian village, his Bubbe (grandmother), uncles, and neighbors must flee to safety. They end up hiding in plain sight of the German army, particularly the German Major who is determined to rid the country of Jews.When the Major discovers the Jews' secret hideout, they leave again, and some of them are captured. Now Anton has no one to help them, but he uses his wits to save his Bubbe and himself. I liked reading about a twelve-year-old boy who used his strengths to help others who were in a dire situation. He certainly wasn't a passive Jew, as some books would have you believe. The setting in Russia was a bonus for me as a reader who enjoys WWII historical fiction stories for youth.

“I loved it.”  A very interesting story of the Jewish experience in the Ukraine during World War II.  The main character “Anton” is a brave, resilient, and amazing twelve-year-old Jewish boy.  Anton and his family are forced from their home and way of life and motivated by survival from the “Evil” Gestapo.  This fictional thriller is a classic game of cat and mouse and is “a must read.”  Brilliantly told revealing the challenges all the characters face during this grim period.  I couldn’t wait to read the next page.  Recommended for every kid to read with their family to learn about history.  You will finish this book better understanding sacrifice and to never take your freedoms for granted.  -GoodReads user by Trevor D.

description: Nazi gun fire can only mean one thing...The Germans are closing in. And twelve-year-old Anton knows his family can't outrun them. A web of underground caves seems like the perfect place to hide. But danger lurks above the surface. Ruthless Major Karl Von Duesen of the Gestapo has made it his mission to round up every Jew in the Ukrainian countryside. Anton knows if his community is discovered, they will be sent off to work camps...or worse.When a surprise invasion catches them off guard, Anton makes a radical decision. He won't run any longer. And he won't hide. He will stop being the hunted...and start doing some hunting of his own. Michael P. Spradlin's newest thriller is the ultimate game of cat and mouse set during one of the darkest moments in history.
title: The Enemy Above: A Novel of World War II
